Additionally, the development of scalable, low-cost, and eco-friendly synthesis routes will be a key to broadening the commercial viability of g-C3N4 electrodes. Smart energy storage applications involve devices that store energy and respond to environmental or external stimuli, such as light, temperature, pressure, or electric fields. These systems are important for wearable electronics, IoT devices, and smart grids. Examples include photosensitive supercapacitors for solar energy harvesting, thermosensitive supercapacitors that adjust performance based on temperature changes, and electrosensitive supercapacitors for real-time energy storage optimization. Flexible supercapacitors are crucial for wearable and foldable devices because of their energy efficiency and mechanical durability under physical stress. These devices offer advantages such as rapid charging, long cycling life, and adaptability, paving the way for more efficient energy management in modern electronics, autonomous systems, and renewable energy solutions. The integration of smart materials such as conducting polymers and carbon nanostructures further enhances the functionality of these devices, making them essential for future energy storage technologies. Integrating advanced technologies such as artificial intelligence and machine learning could optimize design and forecast performance, potentially overcoming current limitations and promoting future energy storage devices. The advancements in flexible supercapacitors and battery-type supercapacitors hold great promise for electric vehicles, portable electronics, and grid storage. By addressing the identified research gaps and leveraging emerging trends, the field can continue to progress toward more efficient, sustainable, and high-performance energy storage solutions. Priyanka Chaluvachar is a researcher and doctoral student at the Department of Aeronautical and Automobile Engineering, Manipal Institute of Technology (MIT), part of the Manipal Academy of Higher Education (MAHE), Manipal, India. Her research focuses on advanced nanomaterials and the computational analysis of molecular dynamics for energy storage applications. She has contributed to the field through publications in academic journals. She has also presented at international conferences showcasing her innovative work on energy storage materials. Y.N. Sudhakar is an Assistant Professor (Senior Scale) at the Department of Chemistry, Manipal Institute of Technology, Manipal Academy of Higher Education (Deemed to be University), Manipal. He completed a doctoral degree at the Manipal Institute of Technology and a postgraduate degree at Mangalore University, Konaje. He currently supervises five research scholars and has supervised more than 45 postgraduate students. More than 70 original and review articles were published, with 50 plus presentations at International and National Conferences and two books and four book chapters in reputed publishers. His current research interest is in Electrochemical energy storage and sensors. G.T. Mahesha is a professor in the Department of Aeronautical and Automobile Engineering at Manipal Institute of Technology, Manipal, India. He has more than 25 years of teaching experience and more than 5 years of research experience. His areas of research interest are green materials, bio-based and eco-friendly materials, alternative fuels, and electric and hybrid vehicles. He has published more than 25 articles in international journals of repute and presented about 20 technical papers at international conferences. Vishnu G Nair received the B.Tech. Degree from Kerala University, India, in 2010, the M.Tech. He earned his Degree from the Manipal Institute of Technology, Manipal, India, in 2012 and his Ph.D. from the National Institute of Technology Karnataka, India, in 2019. He is currently with the Department of Aeronautical Engineering, Manipal Institute of Technology, Manipal Academy of Higher Education. His research interests include control, motion planning, and multi-robotic systems. Nakul Desai is a researcher and a doctoral student at the Department of Chemistry, Manipal Institute of Technology (MIT), Manipal Academy of Higher Education (MAHE), Manipal, India. He holds a master’s in Analytical Chemistry from Christ (Deemed to be University), Bengaluru, India. His area of research focuses on exploring novel electrode materials to improve the sensitivity, selectivity, and stability of sensors and energy storage devices. He has published research articles on sensors and energy storage materials in academic journals and presented his work at international conferences. Dayananda K. Pai is the Head of the Department of Aeronautical & Automobile Engineering at Manipal Institute of Technology (MIT), Manipal Academy of Higher Education (MAHE), Manipal, India, and the Chief Coordinator for NBA, AICTE, IET, and NAAC activities. Holding a B.E. in Mechanical Engineering, an M.Tech. in Production Management, and a Ph.D. in Mechanical Engineering, his areas of interest include composites, manufacturing, design, and optimization. With 30 years of teaching experience and 20 years of research contributions, he has participated in numerous international conferences and served as a peer reviewer for review articles.

coredata.dc:description: Graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4), known for its green and abundant nature and composed of carbon and nitrogen in a two-dimensional structure, has emerged as a significant area of interest across various disciplines, particularly in energy conversion and storage. Its recent demonstrations of high potential in supercapacitor applications mark it as a promising alternative to graphene within the realm of materials science. Numerous favorable features, such as chemical and thermal stability, abundant nitrogen content, eco-friendly attributes, and gentle conditions for synthesis, are shown. This review summarizes recent advancements in the use of g-C3N4 and its composites as electrodes for supercapacitors, highlighting the advantages and issues associated with g-C3N4 in these applications. This emphasizes situations where the composition of g-C3N4 with other materials, such as metal oxides, metal chalcogenides, carbon materials, and conducting polymers, overcomes its limitations, leading to composite materials with improved functionalities. This review discusses the challenges that still need to be addressed and the possible future roles of g-C3N4 in the research of advanced supercapacitor technology, such as battery-hybrid supercapacitors, flexible supercapacitors, and photo-supercapacitors.
